description.narrative: Viet Nam is the second-largest producer of coffee in the world and the largest exporter of Robusta beans. Coffee is the second most important agricultural commodity in Viet Nam, after rice, contributing USD 3 billion to the Vietnamese economy, or roughly two to four percent of its GDP. It also accounts for around 40% of global Robusta production and nearly 60 percent of global Robusta exports. Around 90% of Viet Nam’s coffee production comes from the Central Highlands – the agricultural hub of the country.Vietnamese farmers typically reach yields of more than 3.5 tonnes per hectare, compared to 0.8 tonnes per hectare in Thailand, 0.5 tonnes per hectare in Indonesia, and only 0.4 tonnes per hectare in Lao PDR. While this growth has made a significant contribution to the Vietnamese economy, it has not come without costs. In fact, maintaining such high levels of productivity has generated a series of environmental challenges, including deforestation and ecosystem degradation.Climate change poses another threat to the country’s coffee sector and poor farming techniques cause environmental degradation and water pollution. Also, the agriculture sector is characterized by a stagnant and low share of value adding in the value chain, due to high input costs, variation in production and incorporation of new services. Therefore our project will focus on two important ICSR issues in the coffee value chain in Viet Nam:1. The unequal value distribution in the supply chain leading to a weak economic position of coffee farmers.2. Sustainability (climate change and environment).To mitigate the CSR risks t in the coffee chain in Viet Nam, KoffieDirect will make local coffee farmers co-owner of KoffieDirect. By using new technologies KoffieDirect will integrate farmers in the value chain. In practice, this means that the farmers will get access to the GREENcoffee app (which contains personalised and dynamic advice based on Good Agricultural Practices). The app will connect farmers with Blockchain technology to generate transparency on the transactions with the buyers. By giving farmers access to the existing GREENcoffee app, the farmers will get access to environmental friendly agricultural practices enabling them to reduce inputs without jeopardising yields. In addition, by making farmers co-owner of the value chain, they will be incentivised to work on environmental friendly practices contributing to their livelihood in the longer run.
